S: A teammate and I disagreed on approach and it slowed progress. — I was a student contributor on a team project.
T: I needed to resolve the disagreement quickly and preserve the relationship and deliver academically and keep the team on track.
A: I scheduled a short retro, separated facts from opinions, listed options with pros/cons, and proposed a time‑boxed experiment. I scoped the work, set light-weight rituals, and owned the risky pieces.
R: As a result, we adopted the winning option and finished on time; we kept collaborating well afterwards; we hit the demo date and the instructor highlighted our process.

S: A teammate and I disagreed on approach and it slowed progress. — I was an individual contributor in an internship.
T: I needed to resolve the disagreement quickly and preserve the relationship and unblock the squad without overstepping.
A: I scheduled a short retro, separated facts from opinions, listed options with pros/cons, and proposed a time‑boxed experiment. I paired with peers, documented findings, and raised risks early.
R: As a result, we adopted the winning option and finished on time; we kept collaborating well afterwards; the release landed and my notes became the go‑to reference.

S: A teammate and I disagreed on approach and it slowed progress. — I was the PM pairing with design and engineering.
T: I needed to resolve the disagreement quickly and preserve the relationship and align stakeholders and tie decisions to metrics.
A: I scheduled a short retro, separated facts from opinions, listed options with pros/cons, and proposed a time‑boxed experiment. I wrote a one‑page PRD, framed trade‑offs, and instrumented success metrics.
R: As a result, we adopted the winning option and finished on time; we kept collaborating well afterwards; we shipped incrementally and the KPI moved meaningfully.
